title: Salt-affected soils: discovering a missed reality

tasks.task: Understanding the impact of salt-affected soils on agricultural productivity.
subtasks: Recognizing the presence of saline and sodic soils.
Understanding how soluble salts in saline soils hinder plant water absorption.
Identifying the damage caused by high sodium ions in sodic soils, such as hard and compact drying and sticky when wet conditions.
Acknowledging the reduction in agricultural productivity in salt-affected soils.
Exemplifying regions and practices affected by naturally occurring saline soils, such as the Ayuni salt flat in Bolivia and quinoa real cultivation.

Identifying human-induced drivers of salt-affected soils, including unsustainable agricultural practices, poor irrigation quality, removal of deep-rooted vegetation, water pumping, overuse of fertilizers, and climate change effects.
Understanding the importance of conserving natural ecosystems susceptible to salinization and sodicity.
Emphasizing sustainable soil and water management practices.
Considering the use of appropriate irrigation methods and drought-resistant crops.
Promoting harmony between soil management and natural processes to halt salinization.

tasks.task: Exploring solutions to manage salt-affected soils.
subtasks: Advocating for conservation of natural ecosystems sensitive to salinity.
Promoting sustainable practices in soil and water management.
Encouraging the adoption of appropriate irrigation techniques.
Recommending the use of salt-tolerant crops.
Stressing the importance of integrated soil management approaches.
Highlighting the need for climate change resilience in agricultural practices.
